Graphical abstract The metal-mediated coupling between cis-[PdCl2(CNR1)2] [R1 =cyclohexyl (Cy) 1, t-Bu 2, 2,6-Me2C6H3 (Xyl) 3, 2-Cl-6-MeC6H3 4] and hydrazones H2NNCR2R3 [R2, R3 =Ph 5; R2, R3 =C6H4(OMe-4) 6; R2/R3 =9-fluorenyl 7; R2 =H, R3 =C6H4(OH-2) 8] provided carbene complexes cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NCR2R3)N(H)R1}(CNR1)] (9–24) in good (80–85%) yields. Complexes 9–24 showed high activity [yields up to 99%, and turnover numbers (TONs) up to 3.7×104] in the Sonogashira coupling of various aryl iodides with a range of substituted aromatic alkynes without the need of copper co-catalyst. The catalytic procedure runs at 80°C for 1h in EtOH using K2CO3 as a base. No formation of homocoupling or acetylene decomposition products was observed. Designed copper-free Sonogashira system can also run at room temperature giving target products with yields up to 87% and TONs up to 87. Keywords Acyclic diaminocarbenes Palladium-(acyclic diminocarbene) catalysts Metal-mediated coupling Isocyanides Sonogashira cross-coupling 1 Introduction In the last decades, N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) turned out to be one of the most powerful classes of ancillary ligands [1,2–5], and corresponding NHC-based metal complexes were successfully employed as catalysts in a wide range of organic transformations [4,6–13]. In particular, outstanding accomplishments were achieved in the field of cross-coupling, e.g. in Suzuki–Miyaura and Heck reactions where palladium-NHC catalysts guaranteed some of the highest catalytic efficiencies [6–8,10]. Compared to hundreds of reports describing the use of palladium-NHCs in Suzuki–Miyaura and Heck reactions [7,8], the application of NHCs for Sonogashira coupling is limited to just a dozen of examples [7,8,14–25]. Nearly all known procedures employ high catalyst loading (typically between 1 and 3mol%) [14–25], operate in toxic organic solvents (e.g. dimethylformamide or dimethylacetamide) [14,15,18,19,21–23], frequently require copper co-catalysts [14,15,18,19,21,25], and demand further purification of the target products due to occurrence of side-reactions [8]. Taking into account the constantly growing price of palladium and tightened requirements for greener reaction conditions, the search for alternative catalysts and catalytic systems is due. In the past years, several research groups have demonstrated that acyclic diaminocarbene ligands (ADCs, Scheme 1 –A) are a promising alternative to N-heterocyclic species. Indeed, some of the reported ADC metal complexes catalyze cross-coupling processes with activities comparable or even higher than those of NHCs (for recent reviews and manuscripts on the topic see Refs. [26–32]). In pursuit of our own research on chemistry of acyclic diaminocarbenes [33–39], we found that palladium-ADC complexes prepared via the metal-mediated coupling of N-phenylbenzamidine with palladium-bound isocyanides (Scheme 1–B) work as efficient catalysts for Sonogashira coupling [36]. Despite the fact that the scope of that system is limited, it operates in EtOH (organic solvent with the lowest environmental impact) and requires lower catalyst loading (0.05mol%) when compared to the conventional schemes [36]. Following these initial reports, we decided to evaluate the catalytic properties of other ADC derivatives in Sonogashira reaction. We focused our attention on previously described by some of us palladium-ADC complexes formed via the addition of hydrazones to palladium-bound isocyanides (Scheme 2 ) [38]. These ADC were evaluated previously as catalysts for Suzuki–Miyaura coupling showing an excellent catalytic activity [38]. However, the use of ADC complexes in Sonogashira catalysis is still rare and this field remains almost unexplored [27,28] (see also below). The scenario of our work was the following. Firstly, we prepared a series of palladium-diaminocarbene complexes through the addition of hydrazones to palladium-bound isocyanides. Some of these species were previously reported but we substantially extended the series by application of new hydrazones and new isocyanides. Secondly, we employed the prepared palladium-ADCs as catalysts in the Sonogashira cross-coupling and discovered that they exhibit a remarkable catalytic activity without the need of copper co-catalyst. In addition, we evaluated the efficacy of these complexes prepared in this work at room temperature Sonogashira coupling. Finally, we got some first evidence on the nature of the catalytic species in this palladium-ADC-based system. Our results are disclosed in the sections that follow. 2 Results and discussions 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of palladium-aminocarbene complexes Previously, we reported [38] the coupling of cis-[PdCl2(CNR1)2] [R1 =cyclohexyl (Cy) 1, t-Bu 2, 2,6-Me2C6H3 (Xyl) 3] [35,40–42], and benzophenone hydrazone [IUPAC name: (diphenylmethylene)hydrazine] (5), leading to the corresponding aminocarbene complexes 9–11 (Scheme 2). In the current study, we extended the series by using the new isocyanide species cis-[PdCl2{CN(2-Cl-6-MeC6H3)}2] [35] (4) and three new hydrazones with different donor and sterical properties. Thus, we used 4,4-dimethoxybenzophenone hydrazone [(bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methylene)hydrazine] (6) containing donor substituents in the aromatic ring [43,44], sterically hindered 9-fluorenone hydrazone [(9H-fluoren-9-ylidene)hydrazine] (7), and salicylaldehyde hydrazone [2-(hydrazonomethyl)phenol] (8), that is derived from the corresponding aldehyde (R2 =H). Previously, we reported [38] that the reaction between equimolar amounts of 1–3 and 5 (in all combinations) proceeds in refluxing CHCl3 for ca. 8h. In the current study, we employed nearly similar conditions for the coupling of any palladium-isocyanide complex 1–4 with any of hydrazones 5–8. Therefore, reflux of the reaction mixture in chloroform for ca. 8h [or 12h for the reactions of cis-[PdCl2(CNt-Bu)2] (2)] followed by the appropriate workup, allowed the isolation of the corresponding carbene complexes cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NCR2R3)N(H)R1}(CNR1)] (9–24) in good (80–85%) yields (Table 1 , Scheme 2). The authenticity of the known species 9–11 was established upon comparison of the recorded 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectra (1H NMR) and IR spectra with those previously reported by some of us [38], while the new complexes 12–24 were characterized using (C, H, N) analyses, ESI+-MS (electrospray ionization mass-spectrometry), IR, 1D (1H, 13C{1H}) and 2D (1H,1H-COSY, 1H,13C-HMQC/1H,13C-HSQC, 1H,13C-HMBC) NMR spectroscopies. In addition, the structures of 15, 19, and 24 were elucidated by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 12–24 gave satisfactory C, H, and N elemental analyses, which are consistent with the proposed formulations for cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NCR2 2)N(H)R1}(CNR1)]. The ESI+-MS mass spectra display molecular ion peaks and/or a fragmentation corresponding to the loss of Cl's from the molecular ion, viz. [M− nCl]+, with the characteristic isotopic distribution. The examination of the IR spectra revealed the presence of one strong ν(CN) stretching vibration in the range between 2229 and 2198cm−1, that belongs to the unreacted isocyanide ligand. In the formed carbene moiety, the ν(N–H) bands emerge in the range of 3256–3210cm−1, while the corresponding very strong bands due to ν(Ccarbene–N) stretches appear between 1570 and 1533cm−1. The medium/weak intensity bands in the range of 2980–2836cm−1 are characteristic of the ν s (C–H) and ν as (C–H) vibrations, while medium intensity bands due to δ(С–H from Ar) appear in the range of 698–783cm−1. The 1H NMR spectra of carbene complexes 12–24 display a broad peak in the range of δ 8.83–9.94 assigned to the Ccarbene–N(H)R proton, while the corresponding C carbene–NH 13C signals were found to resonate in the range of 180–165ppm, i.e. they are approximately 65–45ppm downfield shifted in comparison with the 13C signal of the isocyanide in the starting (isocyanide)PdII complexes 1–4 (e.g. 115 ppm for CN in cis-[PdCl2(CNCy)2]). The crystallographic data and processing parameters for 15, 19, and 24 are very similar and are listed in Table 1S of Supplementary Data, while corresponding plots can be found in Figs. 1–3 , respectively. Bond lengths and angles are given in the legends to each plot. In 15, 19, and 24, the chloride ligands are mutually in cis position [Cl1–Pd1–Cl2 in 15: 93.001(15), 19: 91.73(3), Cl1–Pd1–Cl2 in 24: 93.41(9)°]. The slightly distorted square planar environment around the metal center is completed with one unreacted isocyanide ligand, CNR1, and one newly formed carbene ligand, C(N(H)NCR2 2)N(H)R1. The Pd–Ccarbene distances [1.9805(15) in 15, 2.006(3) in 19, and 1.964(10)Å in 24] are comparable to those reported for the similar palladium carbene complexes cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NCPh2)N(H)Xyl}(CNXyl)] (Pd1–C11 1.973(3)Å).[38] In all complexes, the carbene moiety is roughly planar and the angles around the carbene carbon atom range from 116.0(3) to 127.5(2)° therefore sustaining the sp 2 hybridization of this atom. Short and nearly equal (within 3σ) N–Ccarbene bond lengths in 15, 19, and 24 (aver. 1.33Å) imply substantial p π –p π interactions within the diaminocarbene fragments, as detected in the related abovementioned carbene complexes [38]. In the isocyanide ligand, the CN triple bond [1.1499(15) in 15, 1.149(4) in 19, 1.146(10)Å in 24] is of a normal value for triple CN bonds (1.136–1.144Å) [45,46] and is coherent with those observed in the related isocyanide palladium and platinum complexes cis-[PdCl2(CNR1)2] [R1 =Cy (1.128–1.142Å) [47], t-Bu (1.108–1.149Å) [48], Xyl (1.145–1.156Å)] [49]. All other bond lengths in all three complexes are of normal values and they agree with those reported [35–39] for related palladium(II) aminocarbene and isocyanide complexes. 2.2 Catalytic studies Complexes bearing acyclic aminocarbenes were scarcely used in Sonogashira catalysis [27,28]. Indeed, only few examples for both copper-free and copper co-catalyzed protocols were reported up to date. Thus, Dhudshia and Thadani [50] found that the optimized copper-free protocol allowed the transformation of sterically hindered aryl bromides and aromatic- or aliphatic alkynes. The reaction proceeded in a toluene/tetrahydrofuran mixture at room temperature (RT); it required 1.5mol% of palladium-ADC catalyst accomplishing target products in 80–91% yields with the TONs (turnover number=moles of product per mole of catalyst) up to 61. Vasilyev et al. reported [51] on the use of palladium-ADCs for the transformation of aroyl chlorides. Catalytic system required 0.04mol% catalyst loading (and 2mol% of CuI as co-catalyst) and proceeded in benzene or tetrahydrofuran at 60°C giving target products in 52–98% yields. Another copper co-catalyzed Sonogashira system reported recently by some of us [36] enabled the coupling of 4-NO2C6H4I with oct-1-yne (EtOH, K2CO3, 60°C) to yield 1-nitro-2-(oct-1-ynyl)benzene. The palladium-ADC catalyst loading was as low as 0.05 mol%, providing product yields of up to 99%, and TONs up to 2000 [36]. Inspired by our previous findings we evaluated catalytic properties of 9–24 in Sonogashira cross-coupling. 2.2.1 Optimization of the reaction conditions for Sonogashira coupling As a model system for all optimizations, we have chosen the reaction of 4-methoxy-iodobenzene (4-iodoanisole) with phenylacetylene accomplishing 1-methoxy-4-(phenylethynyl)benzene (Scheme 3 ). 2.2.1.1 Effect of base It is known that the Sonogashira reaction is strongly affected by the nature of the base employed. Therefore, we performed a wide base screening in the model coupling (Table 2 ). Based on our previous studies [36], ethanol was employed as the reaction medium for the base optimization. Among bases studied, K2CO3 was the most effective one (entries 13–15, Table 2) at all temperatures; closely related Na2CO3 (entries 10–12) was substantially less effective, in particular, at 20–40°C. Other bases such as NEt3 (entries 1–3), t-BuOK (entries 4–6), KOH (entries 7–9), Cs2CO3 (entries 16–18), or K3PO4 (entries 19–21), were less active or inactive under studied conditions. Moreover, no increase in the product yield was observed when the reaction was performed for longer time at any of the studied temperature (e.g. for 14h instead of 4h at 80°C). As a result, K2CO3 and Na2CO3 were selected as suitable bases. 2.2.1.2 Effect of solvent and temperature As the next step, we verified the effect of solvent at different temperatures (20, 40, and 80°C) using K2CO3 and Na2CO3 as bases (Table 3 ). As can be inferred from inspection of the obtained results, K2CO3 in EtOH (entries 7–12, Table 3) and Na2CO3 in MeOH (entries 1–6) were the most suitable combinations. When K2CO3 or Na2CO3 were used in n-PrOH (entries 13–18), the product yield was significantly lower. Other evaluated solvents, i.e. t-BuOH, toluene, or p-xylene were not efficient with either K2CO3 or Na2CO3 at 20–80°C range (entries 19–36). For further studies, EtOH (with K2CO3 as a base) and MeOH (with Na2CO3) were chosen. Furthermore, the best product yields were achieved at 80°C. 2.2.1.3 Effect of catalyst loading In order to achieve maximum TON, we verified the yield of target product with different catalyst loadings (Table 4 ). A high yield (89%) was obtained with as low as 0.01mol% of catalyst (entry 3, Table 4). The yield of product dramatically dropped with a lower catalyst amount (0.001mol%, entry 4), and no formation of the product was observed without catalyst (entry 1) and with the loading of 0.0001mol% (entry 5). The maximum TON for the system (8.9×103) was achieved with the catalyst loading of 0.01mol% (entry 3). Consequently, the catalyst loading of 0.01mol% was used for further studies. 2.2.2 Screening of the catalytic activity of 9–24 We examined the efficiency of the 9–24 complexes in the model Sonogashira system and the results obtained are summarized in Table 5 . Among the palladium aminocarbenes 9–24, complexes 13, 15, and 24 exhibited the highest efficiencies furnishing the coupling product in 94–97% yield with 0.01mol% (1×10−8 mol) of the catalyst (entries 5, 7, and 16, correspondingly). Catalysts 9 (entry 1, product yield 89%), 11 (entry 3, 89%), 14 (entry 6, 87%), 16 (entry 8, 86%), 17 (entry 9, 88%), 18 (entry 10, 83%), and 19 (entry 11, 86%) were slightly less active. All other tested aminocarbene complexes were significantly less active. The maximum TON of 3.7×104 was accomplished with the catalyst 24 (loading: 0.001mol%, or 1×10−9 mol), however, the yield of the product was only 37%. With higher catalyst loading of 24 (0.01mol%, 1×10−8 mol), the TON was of 9.7×103. With three most active catalysts in our hands (13, 15, and 24), we tried to shorten the reaction time for our catalytic system by using an excess of phenylacetylene (1.5 equivs) instead of stoichiometric amounts employed beforehand. We found out that nearly identical product yields were obtained within 1 h of the reaction (yields were 91% for 13, 88% for 15 or 89% for 24). As the next step, we examined the scope of our catalytic system for various organohalides and found out that several phenyl iodides containing either electron-withdrawing or electron-donating substituents can react with various substituted aromatic alkynes giving the target products in excellent to moderate yields (Table 6 ). No by-products due to acetylene decomposition or homocoupling were detected in any of these trials. Unfortunately, the attempted coupling between 4-bromoanisol or 4-chloroanisol (entries 37–39 and 40–42, correspondingly, Table 4) and phenylacetylene was unsuccessful. It is noteworthy that the reaction of 4-bromoanisol was extensively tested under a wide range of different conditions (Table 2S of Supplementary data). At elevated temperatures (110–130°C) and in the presence of strong bases (e.g. t-BuOK, KOH, or Cs2CO3), the formation of cross-coupling product was observed, however, it was strongly contaminated with 4,4′-dimethoxybiphenyl derived from the homonuclear coupling of 4-bromoanisole. At lower temperatures and with milder bases only trace amounts of the desired product were detected. 2.2.3 Sonogashira coupling at room temperature using 9–24 as catalysts We attempted to run our system at room temperature (Table 7 ). It was found out that under modified conditions [K3PO4 (2.5×10−4 mol, 2.5 equiv), 4-iodoanisole (1.0×10−4 mol, 1.0 equiv), phenylacetylene (1.5×10−4 mol, 1.5 equiv), selected catalyst (1×10−6 mol, 1.0mol%)], the product is formed in 82–87% yield after 24h. Although, as expected, much lower TONs were achieved compared to the trials at higher temperature (80°C). 2.2.4 Attempts of identification of catalytic species Although recent studies aimed to shed light on mechanistic aspects of both copper-mediated and copper-free versions of Sonogashira cross-coupling, their mechanisms are still unclear [52]. With respect to the copper-free process, most of the involved researchers support the hypothesis that the mechanism is based on π-coordination of an alkyne followed by proton removal from alkyne upon action of base that occurs directly at the catalytic center (Scheme 4 ) [52]. However, several studies demonstrated that other components of the catalytic system, e.g. amine (if used as a base), solvent or alkyne can replace the original supporting ligands L (e.g. phosphines) at the catalyst core resulting in different intermediates, and, consequently altering the mechanism of the process. It is worthwhile mentioning that even in the case of extremely popular palladium-NHC species, whose activity in copper-free Sonogashira reaction was documented [7,8,52], only limited evidence on the nature of the active catalytic species was gathered and all proposed mechanisms remain hypothetical. In order to make an approach to mechanism of our ADC-based system, that is structurally relevant to that with palladium-NHC catalysts, we attempted to identify the real catalytic species. In the first set of experiment, we performed several catalytic runs with substrates from Table 6 in the presence of metallic Hg (the mercury drop test [53]). We observed similar reaction rates for the corresponding processes both in the absence and in the presence of metallic Hg for any combination of substrates. These data support an idea that no formation of palladium nanoparticles occurs during the reaction and the catalytic system operates under typically homogeneous conditions. Furthermore, we observed no induction period in the system, and the accumulation of the product in the initial period follows nearly linear time-dependence. In the second set of experiments, we performed ESI-MS monitoring of the reaction mixture for the model catalytic system with 13 [cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NC(C6H4OMe-4)2)N(H)Cy}(CNCy)], C29H38N4Cl2O2Pd, M cat =651.96] as precatalyst (see Figures 1S and 2S, Supplementary data). Before addition of the base to the reaction, only signal corresponding to the [M cat +Na+H]+ [m/z: 674.34 (found), 674.14 (calcd)], was detected in the ESI+-MS spectra. Upon addition of the base, this signal rapidly vanishes giving rise to those with m/z of 615.30 [M cat–Cl2 +2H2O+H]+ (m/z: 615.22, calcd.) and with the m/z of 472.26 (Figure 1S). The latter corresponds to the protonated pure metal-carbene species ([M(carbene)+H]+) (m/z: 472.12 calcd.) generated via the subsequent elimination of the chloride and the isocyanide ligands and reduction of precatalyst 13. This signal remains dominant in the spectra and gradually disappears in the end of the catalytic trial. We believe it is characteristic of the real catalytically active species and being the catalyst resting state. Unfortunately, we were unable to identify by ESI-MS other intermediates of the catalytic cycle (e.g. products of the oxidative addition or alkyne binding to the palladium center) using either ESI-MS or NMR spectroscopy in different solvents that can indicate that these species are rapidly consumed throughout the catalytic cycle. In the end of the catalytic cycle, along with the disappearance of the ([M(carbene)+H]+) species, accumulation of the palladium clusters containing from 2 to 5 palladium atoms, is observed (Figure 2S). Despite the previous reports on catalytic activity of small palladium clusters (see Ref. [54] and references therein), in our case these compounds are not catalytically competent, indeed, no catalysis was observed upon addition of the fresh substrates and the base to the system. It is worthwhile noticing that the formation of the catalytically active metal clusters from the corresponding complexes is known to be inhibited in the presence of the carbene ligands presumably due to their strong binding to the metal center [55]. 3 Final remarks In conclusion, we developed an efficient copper-free Sonogashira protocol that employs palladium complexes with acyclic aminocarbene ligands derived from the metal-mediated coupling of hydrazones and isocyanides. The reported catalytic procedure runs at 80°C for 1h, and employs K2CO3 as cheap inorganic base and EtOH as environmentally benign solvent. It allows the transformation of a range of aryl iodides into the target internal alkynes with the highest obtained yields of 99%, and the maximum TON of 3.7×104. Comparison of our results with systems based on palladium-ADC catalysts (Dhudshia and Thadani [50], 1.5mol% loading; or Kukushkin et al. [36], 0.05 mol%) or with those running under comparable conditions (Li et al. [56]; based on nanosized palladium, 1mol%) clearly indicates that our protocol is substantially more efficient than the previous ones. We also found that our copper-free Sonogashira system can run at room temperature although with a higher catalyst loading (1%mol); K3PO4 and EtOH were employed as base and solvent, respectively. For the latter, the maximum TON was 87, and the achieved product yield was 87%. Finally, we got some first evidence on the nature of the catalytic species formed from the palladium-ADC precatalysts under action of the base and we believe that the [M(carbene)] fragment is responsible for the homogeneous catalysis. Mechanism is expected to be monomolecular and the deactivation of the catalyst proceeds with the formation of the catalytically inactive Pd2–5 clusters. Further studies aiming to establish the full mechanism of the palladium-ADC catalyzed cross-coupling reactions are currently underway in our group. 4 Experimental part 4.1 Materials and instrumentation Solvents, PdCl2, all isocyanides, and hydrazones 5–7 were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. (Bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methylene)hydrazine (8) was synthesized via a known procedure starting from 4,4′-dimethoxybenzophenone [43,44]. The complexes cis-[PdCl2(R1NC)2] (R1 =Cy 1, t-Bu 2, Xyl 3, 2-Cl-6-MeC6H3 4) were prepared as previously reported [35,40–42]. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico. ESI+ mass-spectra were obtained on a VARIAN 500-MS LC ion trap mass-spectrometer in MeOH (or in MeCN) (ion spray voltage: +5kV, capillary voltage: 30V, RF loading: 100%). EI mass-spectra of organic products from the catalytic studies were acquired on a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 SE. Infrared spectra (4000–400cm−1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX instrument in KBr pellets. 1H, 13C{1H} and 19F NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance II+ 400MHz (UltraShield™ Magnet) and Bruker Avance II+ 500MHz (UltraShield™ Plus Magnet) spectrometers at ambient temperature. 4.2 X-ray studies Crystals were immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop and measured at a temperature of 100K (for 15) and 150K (19 and 24). Intensity data were collected using a Bruker Kappa Apex II Duo (for 15) or Bruker Kappa Apex II (for 19 and 24) diffractometers with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ =0.71073) radiation. Crystallographic details for 15, 19 and 24 are listed in Table S1. 4.2.1 For 15 The APEX2 [57] program package was used for cell refinements and data reductions. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-97 [58] program with the WinGX [59] graphical user interface. A multi-scan absorption correction based on equivalent reflections (SADABS) [60] was applied to the data. Structural refinement was carried out using SHELXL-97 [58]. The NH hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier map but constrained to ride on their parent atom, with Uiso =1.5Ueq(parent atom). Other hydrogen atoms were positioned geometrically and constrained to ride on their parent atoms with C–H=0.95–0.98Å and Uiso =1.2–1.5Ueq(parent atom). 4.2.2 For 19 and 24 Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT [61] on all the observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS [60]. Structures were solved by direct methods by using the SHELXS–97 package [58] and refined with SHELXL–97 [58]. Calculations were performed using the WinGX System–Version 1.80.03 [59]. Hydrogen atoms were inserted in calculated positions. For 24, the quality of the data was poor due to the poor crystal quality and weak diffraction. Least square refinements with anisotropic thermal motion parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms and isotropic for the remaining atoms, were employed. 4.3 Synthetic work 4.3.1 Synthesis of the aminocarbene complexes 9–24 A solution of any of the hydrazones (5–8; 0.20mmol) in CHCl3 (2mL) was added to a solution of cis-[PdCl2(R1NC)2] (0.20mmol) in CHCl3 (5mL) and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 8h (R1 =Cy 1, Xyl 3, 2-Cl-6-Me-C6H3 4) or 12h (R1 = t-Bu 2). During this period, the color of the mixture gradually turned from light orange to bright yellow. The reaction mixture was further evaporated to dryness at 20–25°C under a stream of dinitrogen, and the solid residue was extracted with two 5-mL portions of CHCl3. The bright yellow solution was filtered off to remove some insoluble material, the filtrate was evaporated at RT to dryness under a stream of N2, and washed with two 5-mL portions of i-Pr2O, one 5-mL portion of cold (5°C) Et2O, and again with two 5-mL portions of i-Pr2O, and then dried in vacuo at 20–25°C. Yields of 9–24 were 80–85%, based on the metal. The authenticity of the known species 9–11 was established upon comparison of the recorded 1H NMR and IR spectra with those previously reported by some of us [38]. (12). Anal. (24). Anal. Calcd for C23H20N4Cl4OPd: C, 44.80; H, 3.27; N, 9.09. Found: C, 44.62; H, 3.26; N, 8.98. ESI+-MS, m/z: 616 [M+H]+, 580 [M−Cl]+. IR (KBr, selected bands, cm−1): 2986–2856m ν(C–H), 2200 s ν(CN), 1610 s ν(NC), 1553 s ν(N–Ccarbene), 783m δ(С–H from Ar). 1H NMR (CDCl3, δ): 9.91 (s, 1H) and 8.73 (s, 1H, Ccarbene–(NH)NH), 8.22 (s, 1H, OH), 7.61–7.32 and 7.17–6.95 (m, 10H, aryls), 3.51 (s, 1H, CH), 2.60 and 2.35 (s, 6H, Me). 13C{1H} NMR (CDCl3, δ): 164.7 (Ccarbene–NH+CN), 158.2 (C–OH), 136.8 (CN), 132.6–127.5 (aryls), 119.7 (CN), 31.2 and 22.8 (Me). 4.3.2 General procedure for the catalytic Sonogashira cross-coupling Selected base (1.5×10−4 mol, 1.5 equivs), aryl iodide (1.0×10−4 mol, 1.0 equiv) and terminal alkyne (1.0×10−4 mol, 1.0 equivs) were mixed in a 10-mL vial, followed by addition of a solution of the selected catalyst (1×10−8 mol) in EtOH (1mL). The vial was placed in a preheated oil bath at 80°C and stirred for 4h. After cooling to ca. 25°C, the reaction mixture was evaporated to dryness under a stream of dinitrogen followed by addition of 1.0 equiv of 1,2-dimethoxyethane (NMR internal standard), and extraction of the reaction mixture with three 0.20-mL portions of CDCl3. All fractions were joined and analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The product peak assignments were based on authentic samples or on published data [56,62–68] (several sources were used for published compounds), while the structure of two new products, i.e. 3,4-dimethoxy-5-(phenylethynyl)benzaldehyde (derived from the coupling of 3-iodo-4,5-dimethoxybenzaldehyde with phenylacetylene) and 1-fluoro-2-[(2-methylphenyl)ethynyl]benzene (prepared from 2-fluorophenylacetylene and 2-iodotoluene were undoubtedly established using NMR spectroscopy, MS and elemental analyses (see Supplementary data). Quantifications were performed upon integration of the selected peak of the product in the 1H NMR relatively to the peak of the standard. coredata.dc:description: The metal-mediated coupling between cis-[PdCl2(CNR1)2] [R1 =cyclohexyl (Cy) 1, t-Bu 2, 2,6-Me2C6H3 (Xyl) 3, 2-Cl-6-MeC6H3 4] and hydrazones H2NNCR2R3 [R2, R3 =Ph 5; R2, R3 =C6H4(OMe-4) 6; R2/R3 =9-fluorenyl 7; R2 =H, R3 =C6H4(OH-2) 8] provided carbene complexes cis-[PdCl2{C(N(H)NCR2R3)N(H)R1}(CNR1)] (9–24) in good (80–85%) yields. Complexes 9–24 showed high activity [yields up to 99%, and turnover numbers (TONs) up to 3.7×104] in the Sonogashira coupling of various aryl iodides with a range of substituted aromatic alkynes without the need of copper co-catalyst. The catalytic procedure runs at 80°C for 1h in EtOH using K2CO3 as a base. No formation of homocoupling or acetylene decomposition products was observed. Designed copper-free Sonogashira system can also run at room temperature giving target products with yields up to 87% and TONs up to 87.
